subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Rather, there are two phonemes in English, one of which is pronounced [d] in essentially all dialects, and the other is pronounced in one of several ways.
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Yes, of course! But that just means that in Spanish [d] and [D] are
> allophones and in English they are phonemes.

Rather, there are two phonemes in English, one of which is pronounced
[d] in essentially all dialects, and the other is pronounced in one
of several ways. The important point is the existence of a contrast,
not the particular way in which the contrast is represented in sounds.

--
Go, and never darken my towels again! John Cowan
--Rufus T. Firefly http://ccil.org/~cowan

> Yes, of course! But that just means that in Spanish [d] and [D] are 
> allophones and in English they are phonemes.

Rather, there are two phonemes in English, one of which is pronounced
[d] in essentially all dialects, and the other is pronounced in one
of several ways.  The important point is the existence of a contrast,
not the particular way in which the contrast is represented in sounds.
